title: 2017 Personality 01: Introduction
description:
In this lecture, I define personality from multiple angles, historical, constructivist, psychoanalytic, behavioral and neuropsychological. Personality is a way of looking at the world, and a characteristic mode of behaving. It's both stable and adaptively dynamic. 

--- SUPPORT THIS CHANNEL ---

there's lots of different places that

one of the things that I've been struck

it's not obvious that your personality

you know a human being is a strange

multi-level thing and you might ask

know is your mother more a part of you

sort of subcomponents of a person none

that's part of a province and that's

that's part of an ecosystem and how you

and one of the things that you have to

do as a clinical psychologist for

think well this person's dreadfully

consider someone who's unhappy and
desperate because they no longer have a

they're not doing very well but the fact

that they no longer have an income is
actually something with dramatic

practical consequences and treating that

which they're embedded in their family
because and this is something that we'll

to discussing Freud is that well you

know it's not like everybody's families
are necessarily particularly happy

places to be
you know I mean human beings are very

dependent we have a very long period of
dependency partly because we're so

something that's vaguely capable of
maneuvering on its own and that produces

of course the very tight familial bonds

sometimes the fundamental problem is is

has been identified as the problem
person it's rather convenient for

everyone who's involved to make that

this is the Freudian idea fundamentally
this is the Oedipal idea that it's very

easy for people to become over dependent

to facilitate that and then for the

individual in fact to become free of the

that they can exist as independent

there are cultural variations in that
that make that proposition complex but

that's a fundamental tenant say of

Western orientation one of the
fundamental presuppositions is that part

of the hallmark of positive
psychological development is the

creation of an individual that's capable

would say an implicit ideal that lurks
at the bottom of the clinical

presuppositions of all the theorists
that are classic psychologists

so now it's a very old picture it's
Jonah

emerging from the whale it's a variant

that's a st. George story and sometimes

voluntary contact with that that

in the hope that a clear encounter will

and I would say that that's just a
variant of the manner in which human

more in relationship to Piaget because

you always learn when you're wrong which
is very annoying now what do you learn

when you're correct you you're walking

world you have a sense of what you want

it's also good because if you get what

right the outcome that you get what you
want

indicates no error on the part of your

that's unpleasant because you don't get

you're faced with a problem and the

maybe you're not as funny as you think

maybe you're not around people that who

potential for various paranoid thoughts
